content.description:
Start to the right of the unknown sport line 5.9 and climb up to the wide crack at the beginning.  mount/ balancing your way on top of the ledge, to the crux sequence moving up the diagonal finger crack  

 anyone know if this is in an old guidebook/ who got the FA?I named this in coordination with the theme of Emily prime/ snakeboy. Also this could be harder than 5.11, I had a hard time trying to pull the upper crux moves cleanly
content.location: To the left of Emily Prime and to the right of Unnamed Sport 5.9

content.description: Short, one move wonder route that feels more like a highball boulder problem.  Start right of the bolts to get into the pit, clip the first bolt, move left, clip the 2nd, and jump to a great jug. Follow more jugs to the top.
content.location: Easy to identify the smooth wave like formation on the right side of the canyon when heading upstream. A few minutes past the entrance area (with the log and the splitter 5.10 route), right where the canyon tightens down.

content.description: Climb up face just right of dihedral.
content.location: This is the 3rd route one encounters when hiking up-canyon from 89a.  It is directly right of the unnamed 5.8, with which it shares an anchor.

content.description: A short & easy sport line to a bolted anchor.  Work up arete, then up & right into a corner to a bolted anchor that is shared with another route immediately right.
content.protection: several bolts to a bolted anchor.
content.location: This is the second established route one encounters when hiking up-canyon from 89a.  It is located on the left side of the canyon, just past the unnamed splitter crack on the right side, and shares an anchor with another sport route immediately rock-right.

content.description:
This a very nice (albeit short) route, and IMHO the best route in Lower Pumphouse.  It has fun moves on great rock.  

  Steep face moves lead past a few bolts to a crux near the top.  The crux is protected with a nut and/or a .5-ish Camalot.
content.protection: A few bolts, a medium-large nut and/or .5-ish Camalot, and chains.
content.location:
Boulder hop up-canyon a couple minutes from the Unnamed 5.10a sport route (located on the wall with 4 sport routes) until you get to a nice staging area on the right side with 2 bolt lines.  This is the right route. 

  It is about 5 minutes up-canyon from the un-named 5.10 crack.

content.description:
The furthest right of the 4 sport lines on the wall.  This is an OK sport line if you are in the area.   

  Also I am told that the other 3 sport routes on this wall are decent and all go at 5.10b/c-ish.  However, I have not climbed them and therefore did not enter them into the database.  If anyone has experience with these routes please feel free to add them.
content.location: Walk a couple minutes up-canyon from the unnamed 5.10b crack to a (relatively) larger wall on the right with 4 sport climbs on it.  This is the right-most climb.

content.description: Do an easy but funky move to get on the rock.  Face climb past 2 bolts to get to the crack.  A short crux (.75 camalot?) leads to a nice handcrack, which leads to a bolted anchor.
content.protection: 2 quickdraws, plus a single set of cams from .75 thru #3 camalots. An optional #4 camalot can help protect the transition from face to crack. Lower Offs.
content.location: This is the first established route encountered while hiking up-canyon from 89a.  It is an obvious splitter crack on the right with 2 bolts down low.

content.description:
Instead of climbing the bolted sport lines, climb straight up the crack! There are plenty of spots for good gear placements, and it makes for a much more engaging climb. Good for newer trad climbers too

 *also if someone has info on who got the FA / what this trad line was originally named I can update the description
content.location: To the right of unnamed sport 5.8, and to the left of the unnamed sport 5.9

content.description: Odd start, sorta contrived but the fun is up higher. No real crux, just fun hero climbing at the top on really good holds. Very overhung, but relax, great holds will appear.
content.location: In a up-canyon-left cove just after an obvious square arete. Seconds up from the first bolts in the canyon.

content.description: Wide Fun! Kneebars, stemming, chicken-wings some face holds inside. The Crux is the spider webs!
content.protection: None if you like OW's, BigBros if you need 'em.
content.location: Behind and around the corner from the 5.10 wall. Big fat arete behind a tree.

content.description: Thin powerful start to a big move to a bad/good sloper. Cutting here will swing you in to your belayer. A powerful line with some sandy sloping edges. Sketchy last clip at the top as you move right to the anchors!
content.location: Just up from the first lines encountered in the canyon on the left, obvious short arete. But fun!

content.description: Nice line, fun crux after 3rd(?) bolt, find a nice right hand crimp and bump to a better edge. A bit of a run-out at the top.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors. You can use a #2 i think near the top if run-outs aren't your thing.
content.location: On the obvious 5.10 wall up canyon right, couple of minutes from the first (mixed) line encountered in the canyon. This is the second line from the right on this wall.

content.description: Bouldery start to a sturdy move mid-wall, if I recall you have to trust a decent left side pull to clip and slap past for a better hold.
content.location: The third route from the right on the obvious and in your face canyon right 5.10 wall, just a couple of minutes up from the first mixed line encountered in PH.

content.description: Climb up featured rock that is littered with jugs, hand jams and generally fun climbing. Route was cleaned on rappel. Some loose rock may still exist but overall quality is quite good. On the first ascent I forgot my shoes and had to borrow Iain’s. They did the job but happened to be two sizes too small...Ouch! The anchor is currently a sling and quick link on a large tree just behind the one that can be seen at the top of the route. A proper bolted anchor will be added soon.
content.location: Route is on the right hand side just as you move upstream from the cove area.

content.description: A beautiful line up a steep slab with nice moves.
content.protection: 2 bolts, #1, #3 and medium stoppers to anchors.
content.location: Just past the BIG log in the Centerfold Corner, canyon right. Left side of the dihedral.

content.description: Fun technical face climbing on slightly delicate rock. Past the last bolt is lichen covered rock that will clean up with time.
content.location: Walk down the wash for 10-15 minutes until you see the obvious grey face on canyon left directly to the left of Unnamed Arete (11+)

climbs.name: Ready to Rumble A.K.A. Miss November

content.description: Left Line (1st bolt) is the Original line. Stick clip! Thin moves on sandy edges. Right Line is the good hands crack about 6' to the Right of the Arete. A couple of good hands pieces will protect this .10a line well. Big jug shows up to make getting to the 2nd bolt cruiser. The fun begins after that through the 3rd bolts where perplexing crux delivers. Stay left for reward or bail right if you can't hang.Get ready to rumble.
content.protection: LEFT SIDE 5 bolts to anchors. RIGHT SIDE 2 hand size pieces in the first 10' then clip the 2nd bolt. After ledge a medium nut placed horzontally on the upper portion can help to protect a bit of a run-out (5.8 climbing) to the anchors for those who wish.
content.location: Right arete of Centerfold Corner 30 or so feet past a big fallen log.

content.description:
Start at the base of a prominent arete. Bust some thuggy moves on big holds and fingercrack pods just right of the first bolt. Clip the bolt and transition left to an super fun layback rail to a break near the 2nd bolt. Interesting movement and rock leads up a few more bolts with slightly easier climbing. Clip the last bolt and do some very techy/balancey moves up a vertical crimp rail and slapping the arete.  

  Clipping the chains will be a lot harder if you are short!
content.protection: 5 bolts -- 2 bolt anchor. Very well protected route.
content.location:
Hike up past the initial area (with the log and the splitter 5.10 crack), through the tight cove (past the 11+ arete route). The route is on the left when heading up canyon about 50m past the wave route.   

  Afternoon shade/morning sun.

content.description: The Little Things. A reminder that not all good things have to be big and bold. This was my first bolted sport route, and it serves as a milestone for my route development. Scalloped sandstone invites you toward a head wall of black and brown oxidization with crisp horizontal openings and unique patina shapes.
content.location: -----Warning: This route has an added approach.-----A nice corridor of sandstone houses the Unnamed 5.10 Wave route, as well as the popular Unnamed Cove route, about five minutes past the first routes upwash from the bridge. Above this area on the right (East) is a low angle scramble followed by a short section of fourth class, that approaches an old campsite and some walls with potential. Past the site and up the hill a bit is a North Facing wall, (among others) with a built landing and a promise for good climbing. The climb is also located beneath a large pine tree looming atop the cliffs edge.

content.description: Fun arete climbing up rock that is better than it looks. Real fun movement for the grade! Crux is a balancey move before the last bolt.
content.protection: 4 Bolts to 2 bolt anchor with chains
content.location: On the arete to the right of Unnamed sport 5.8.

content.description: A fun line up a deep dihedral. Big holds, sinker jams, good spots to place gear. This is a great line for a beginning leader. Great movement between nice ledges.
content.protection: .5 to #4, double #3's. Shares anchors with Tap It.
content.location: Huge open book dihedral up-canyon right just past the BIG log across the canyon.

content.description:
Short cragging on sandstone in a beautiful, shady canyon.  Mostly sport, but a few trad routes also.  Rock quality ranges from very good to not so good.  This is a nice place to beat the heat when the rest of Sedona is baking hot. 

  To the best of my knowledge, most routes were put up by Dave Pastor and are unnamed.  If anyone has more info, please contribute anything you can provide.
